This is my dual extrusion tribute to the Detroit Lions.
Cannot print till tomorrow as I am on Vacation. I am thinking Blue and Black for the colors.

Hi,
take a look at my other designs https://www.thingiverse.com/mg_evolution/designs

I designed this as a base for my remix light saber - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2741169
I have printed a Kylo Ren Helmet and I have designed this to sit the helmet on as a stand. When the helmet is removed the light saber and base is then on show.

There are a few different files attached.

First_Order_Base.stl is a complete item. Best to print it in sections though.

First_Order_Base_Surround.stl is printed or painted Red
First_Order_Base_back_with_holes.stl is printed or painted Black. Fits in surround but is a bit loose.
First_Order_Base_Plate_dowels.stl is printed or painted in Red. This fits only one way in to back with holes.

The template is to allow holes to be drilled into other materials (wood/Metal etc) to allow the plate with dowels to fit in.

Most parts will need gluing.

I made the back with holes out of stainless for the main plate and then a piece of steel welded behind in the center, This will allow https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2741169 Kylo Ren light Saber to stick to the base plate on top of plate dowels.

I have printed off all the parts and everything looks to line up just fine. I am currently painting the parts ready to test.
Built using Tinkercad

Notes:

Printed in pieces, using S3D. Printed in Hatchbox ABS white. Extruder temp was set to 220C, print bed was set to 105C for layer 1 and 90C from layer 5 up, and fan cooling was 0 until detail layers.

The only part that had trouble printing was the palm section, which was printed in the propoer orientation to allow for a better finihs on the exterior side. I used the palms with built in supports and had S3D supports for the interior circle section. This did require additional cleanup or snipping the supports and peeling the remaining pieces off. I also dropped the part through the bed slighly to allow for a bidder footprint for the tips of the palms to stick to.

title: Vive motion control magnetic charging dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This enclosure will store a USB splitter, two magnetic charging cables and a USB extension. It can be screwed together with two small screws and works great for my desktop setup. Magnetic charging cables can be glued / epoxied in.

When securing the magnetic charging cables be sure the base of the magnetic end is pushed in to the start of the USB wire not just the end of the metal magnetic head. This will allow for an area where the glue / epoxy can pool and solidify. Additionally it will ensure the magnetic head sits far enough through to account for the indentation on the controller charge port.

Print area of the enclosure is 140mm diameter x 130mm high so you'll need a pretty good build volume to do it in one shot.

author: kerim42407

description.text:
Happy New Year!

I decided to make these to make carrying poles easier. I am sure there are other ways to make it easier, but I like 3D printing (LOL). This fits all the poles we had, so I am sure it fits most sizes.

Almost all ski poles I have seen have little notches at the bottom so you can interlock the two together for a relatively weak bond. Although this is useful, this holder makes it easier to keep together for easy storage and transportation! Feel free to use both mechanisms for keeping poles nice and organized!

I recommend using different colors, if you have them, to color-code the poles so people know whose are whose.

I have too many empty spools laying around from all kinds of different manufacturers. They're all different sizes and I found keynes87's openscad file but it wasn't quite what I wanted.

Using that file as a template, I added some variables and made it work for me. I've added comments to each variable to indicate what measurement to input.

Inner - The RADIUS of the center of the spool in MM
Outer - The RADIUS of the outside of the spool in MM
Thick - Wall thickness in MM - I used 2 mm
Height - Height (inside to inside) of the spool in MM (when laying flat)
Central_Angle - How much of the spool in degrees the drawer will cover - 180 for 2 drawers, 90 for 4 and 45 for 8
Screw_Size - DIAMETER of the screw hole in MM
Screw_Wall - This is a little trickier, but it is the size of the circle around the screw. It needs to be larger than the screw_size. I found that a smaller value here (in MM) made for a slightly quicker render and print time. However, it also moves the pivot point of the drawer closer to the edge of the spool. Too small a value here and there won't be any "meat" on the spool to drill into.
Handle_length - How far out the little handle sticks out

You can open it up in the Customizer and change all these without having to bother with OpenScad.

To Do: I'd like to add a spot for a label on the outside of the drawer, haven't gotten that far in OpenScad yet.

Let me know if something doesn't work for you!

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.32

Infill:

12

title: 3D periodic table
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a rotary cylindrical periodic table with hexagonal patterns (That reminds to a carbon nanotube), where each element show its abbreviation, mass and atomic weight, therefore, it is very useful and didactic, as well as artistic.

Diameter: 199.4 mm
Total height (full assembly): 324 mm
Total weight: 759 g

You can see the 3D model in real time here: http://a360.co/2lu27wQ
And here, my disposition of colors: http://a360.co/2DEzm83
Watch this video to see the finished model: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0B7zKwwB8DA
And this to know about the idea of assembly: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d52YoaQfFIk

If you like this design, please let me know.

If you want to print this, to clarify possible doubts, you must first read all the following information:

Body
• For some printers, printing the hexagonal pattern can be a bit difficult without supports. If you print it on PLA with a lot of ventilation, there should be no problems. I use a layer height of 0.3 mm, 100% layer fan and only support for a specific part (see attached images). I include a STL called "Test" to see if your printer will be able to correctly print the body of the periodic table with its patterns, if you have doubts.
• Important: You have to join the Honey Body Bottom and Honey Body Bottom top in the correct position, in the images you can see a suggestion for you to guide.
• To join the two parts of the body, I recommend first sanding the contact surface a little. Then apply a glue. In my case, I used a glue called "La gotita" (that is the name of the glue in my country, but I know that also it is known like cyanoacrylate or super glue) with sodium bicarbonate. This combination generates a very strong union.


Ball Bearing
• I designed the ball bearing to be printed with a layer height of 0.175 mm, so it is better to respect it.
• I recommend printing it with a speed equal or lower than 50 mm/s. 
• It includes a support that ensures that it prints well. It must be easy to remove. The ball bearing work well.


Elements
• Each element is joined by pressure.
• Before printing all the elements, it is a good idea to print a test and see that they fit well in the hexagonal pattern. Depending on your printer, a small scale may be necessary to fit securely. For example, in my case, I had to scale them on the x and y axis by 100.3% (0.3% larger in those axes) , and with that, they fit very well by pressure.
• You can find the elements ordered in groups in the uploaded files.
• You can choose the colors you want. In my case, I gave colors respecting the visible electromagnetic spectrum, and because I did not have an extra color to the halogens (it would have been great to print them of dark blue and the noble gases of violet), I included them inside the nonmetals group.
• The filament change technique allows the hexagon to have a color, and the element abbreviation, mass and atomic weight, another color, which generates a contrast that allows distinguishing it better. Since my printer is a “Prusa MK2” I use the page https://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/ to do the filament change. I do not know if this method works for other printers, but you have other options:
* Using Simplify3D (I don’t know methods for other slicers)
Watch this video and read its description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OiixypnOS8o
* Manually:
It is more tedious, but you can pause the impression and change the filament, at the desired moment.
I use Fusion360

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W Night Vision Camera Mount

description.text:
This includes the parts required to mount a night vision camera for a Raspberry Pi Zero W, and run an OctoPrint setup, with camera, connected to printer, all contained within a single unit, on a tilt-adjustable Go Pro mount.

The camera tightly mounts into the chasis with the Raspberry Pi Zero W cable attached. The chasis bolts together with 4 - M3 bolts. The raspberry Pi zero W bolts in-place with 4 -M3 bolts and 4 M3 nuts. The Go-pro mount attaches with a M3 bolt and nut. Finally, the entire thing bolts to your chasis.

Wiring involves three cables. One cable to the printer, one cable to power, and the USB-OTG cable connects to the Raspberry Pi Zero W.

Parts Required:
2- M4 x 8 bolts
2- M4 nuts
1- m3 x 20 bolt
5- m3 nut
8- M3 x 8 bolts

Raspberry Pi Zero W $10: https://www.adafruit.com/product/3400
Raspbery Pi Night Vision Camera $26: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0748KF97S
USB-OTG cable $7: https://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Micro-USB-Data-Transfer-connecting-compatible/dp/1059950073

title: Low Poly Fantasy World - The Castle

description.text:
A little fantasy castle. It can be printed as a whole or as triangle pieces. There are 2 different pieces, print both 3 times and you have a full castle. The whole castle version I printed Is scaled down to 50%. As pieces they have feet extensions so the sharp edges stay better on the platform, you can then just clip them off. For the pieces version printing with brim is still recommended while the whole version is easier to print since it does not have the sharp triangle edges.

It can be printed in full color as well as regular single color. Or just paint it how you like.

There is a source mesh version and a remeshed version. If your slicer does not like the original just use the files with "DynaMeshed-Fixed" in the name.

There are also little connection bits you can print so you can put it tightly together when printed as pieces.

Check out other tiles of the fantasy world here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/Davision3d/collections/low-poly-fantasy-world
More are coming.

It originated from the video game Last Knight and its 3D map, check out the intro trailer where you fly through them: https://youtu.be/UoBhmJC8iQE
Or fly through the world yourself over at Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/4629b972551c4faf89e6dead5f5fe705
You can find the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/262210/Last_Knight_Rogue_Rider_Edition/

While I also created the Low Poly Fantasy Tabletop figures (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1244599) they are not compatible with the world pieces but you could always scale these tiles up to to match the figures though that would need to be lots bigger.

title: FT Gremlin  - Chad Lewis Frame - EMax Camera Mount

description.text:
You have a EMax Baby Hawk and just bought the Flite Test Gremlin Chad Lewis carbon fiber frame (best there is!) to re-Frame your Baby Hawk guts but ..... the EMax Camera does not fit the included camera mount because it was designed for their power pack. Problem Solved! This camera mount will give you what you need to mount the stock Baby Hawk camera and provide all the protection the Chad Lewis frame provides. Except the camera harness which needs to be lengthened a bit, all the other parts just drop in without mod.

There is 2 versions, 1 with 3mm screw threads designed in and one with through holes. There is also some spacers since the Flite Test M3 Long screws are a bit too long and don't leave much thread room left for the screw that comes in from the other side.

If you print the threaded one then print at 0.1mm layer heights; else 0.2 should be fine.

Steal a small rubber band from your child for making those rubber band bracelets or order a pack on eBay or Amazon for next to nothing. They are used to hold the camera to the mount and go over the top and across the pegs that come out to the sides; I use 2, one over the lens and one over the circuit boards where the NTSC / PAL switch is. They come in handy for securing other things in your RC fleet so buying a bag of them would be good.

I can print you a couple mounts if you don't have a printer; find me on 3DHubs. (https://www.3dhubs.com/service/3DMyers)

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

Ultra 3D

Rafts:

No

Yes

100um

35%

Notes:

If you print the one with the M3 threads then print at 100um otherwise 200um is fine. There is not much area for infill because it is so small so infill percentage is not that important; run your normal amount.

I printed mine in PETg, but anything will work for this. It is design to carry a bit of the crash load as it's part of the standoffs in the frame like the original.

print_settings.Notes:: PLA

description.text:
Material: PLA

.05 mm for resolution is likely NOT necessary. I just wanted it to be as precise as possible and work backwards from there. If you have success with lower resolution prints of this file, I'd love to hear about it.

This is a very thin print (0.035"). They are the same thickness as the commercial steel moonclips as to not interfere with the operation of the revolver.

After printing, wrap some thin 220+ sand paper around a Bic pen or something similar in diameter and gently smooth the insides that support the neck of the cartridge. Be careful not to remove material from the narrow part of the clip that holds the cartridge in place. The cartridges should wiggle a little once in place. This is necessary for variations in neck diameters between manufactures and also for ease of dropping in and removing the loaded moon clip from the cylinder.

These are meant to be disposable. Use at your own risk. Much easier to load/unload by hand compared to steel moonclips.

This is a collaborative project between my brother and I. I sent him a scanned image of a factory steel moonclip and the necessary dimensions. He then used that as a template layer and created the file using CAD. After only 4 iterations of tweaking, we got it right.

title: Da Vinci Pro bracket for fans

description.text:
I wanted to install the Extruder Fan supports designed by shotgun_banjo on my Da Vinci Pro. I didn't want glue on the extruder carriage.
By using this brackey it is not required anymore to tape of glue the Fan Supports to the carriage. The Bracket can easily be mounted with a single ziptie.

In my machine I have installed two 12V radial fans.
The position of the fans can be altered to the optimal position because there is room to slide the fan supports sideways on the bracket.
As a result of this setup the printing quality of PLA has improved a lot.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6DUOEAY3IyJ

Thanks to both Shotgun_banjo and ChattoBrian for their designs and inspiration.

The back-face of the base for mounting this bracket is based on the Da Vinci Pro Fan Duct by ChatToBrian

title: BLTouch Mount for PrintRite DIY 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple mount for a BLTouch Bed Level Sensor for a PrintRite DIY 3D Printer. It mounts on the right side of the extruder carriage using the heatsink and the BLtouch hangs down below it.

Print it with the small tabs on the print bed and the large mounting tab with three holes pointing straight up.

Shape down the two small tabs with a file or sandpaper so that they are a tight press fit into the fins of the heatsink, then secure with a small sheet metal screw that bites in between the heatsink fins.

This does reduce the print area by about 8-10mm to the right, so be aware of that.

This sensor, plus a PEI sheet on my heated bed have been the best of many upgrades I've made to my PrintRite. The BLTouch completely eliminates fiddling with the crappy Z-Axis endstop to set the nozzle height before every print. I've gone from about a 40% first layer failure rate to almost 0% now.

Note:

Please don't ask me for advice on installing a BLTouch with the provided firmware or control board. I don't know if it will work. I have long ago switched my control board out for a SmoothieBoard clone and have no intention to go back and try it. The BLTouch should work with most control boards based on an Arduino Mega running Marlin (RAMBo,etc.) or Smoothie boards.

description.text:
Ho voluto progettare questo arco di luce per la mia Anet A8 principalmente perchè non ero riuscito a trovare un modello che mi piacesse sia qui su Thingiverse sia su altri siti, inoltre che si integrasse con la stampante senza occupare troppo spazio e che potesse anche nascondere i cavi di collegamento il più possibile, infatti questo arco una volta montato ha una cavità interna che lo percorre interamente permettendo il passaggio dei cavi di alimentazione della striscia led e di poterli nascondere, inoltre i cavi contribuiscono ulteriormente a irrigidire la struttura in quanto la tengono in tensione dall'interno.
Prima della creazione del gcode le tre parti vanno ruotate e appoggiate alla base.
Per la striscia led va bene una comunissima striscia da 10 mm di larghezza, possibilmente da 12V da poterla collegare allo stesso alimentatore della vostra Anet A8, anche questa poi dopo averla tagliata su misura la dovete incollare alla base contro il piccolo dente.

title: Toilet Seat slide-preventer / alignment block (parametric, customizable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement toilet seat bumpers that include a hook to keep the seat from sliding left or right in case of a "hard landing".

Helps to save the bolts and hinges from loosening or breaking when someone puts high sideways force on the toilet seat.

Note: this design only works on toilet seats with removable feet/bumpers which have two pin holes.

There are other similar designs that already exist (here and here), but I wanted something that would hook on the outside instead of the inside, for cleanliness sake.

Instructions:

You will need some Information in order to customize the design for your toilet seat. Remove one of the bumpers from your toilet seat and measure:

  • the diameter of the pins
  • the distance between the pins (on-centre)
  • the width, length, and height of the bumper (exclusive of the pins)
  • the distance from the outside end of the bumper to the outside edge of the toilet bowl

Customize the design and print. You will need to print one "clip" and two "pins" for each side.

Take the pins and insert them in to the holes on the printed "clip". I recommend you insert the pins with the rounded end on the outside. You may need to use a small knife to trim around the edge of the holes first, depending on how much first-layer "squish" your printer has.

Insert the whole assembly in to the holes from the original bumper, ensuring the flange is facing the outside of the toilet.

Close the seat and make sure the flange is the correct distance from the outside edge of the toilet bowl. It should touch (or come close) but not be tight.

Printer:

CloverPlus (Kossel-mini-based)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Doesn't matter

Infill:

= 20%

Notes:

Because this will receive significant force on the flange, I would recommend at least 20% infill and at least 1mm of top, bottom, and wall thickness.

I printed with PLA, which is very rigid, and so you may need to increase wall and infill if using a more flexible filament such as ABS or PET-G.

I recommend printing with a neutral colour filament to avoid clashing with your decor. If you choose to paint it, remember to use a mold- and bacteria-resistant oil-based paint.

title: Fan Duct for Anycubic i3 Mega with V6 Hotend and Sensor Holder

description.text:
This is a fan duct for the Anycubic i3 Mega with a V6 hotend. The fan duct can hold a capacitive or inductive sensor. This fan duct gives a good downward cooling without affecting the heater block.

The V6 hotend must be connected directly without spacer.

You simply stick in the fan in the opening. I use the following fan: https://www.amazon.com/UEETEK-Printer-Cooling-Cooler-Heatsinks/dp/B06XDS15W1

The sensor clip holds a 12mm capacitive or inductive sensor.

You can use the original V6 cooler fan duct for the heatsink.

Work in progress: The lower threaded holder is not yet in the right position... it should be a bit higher.

description.text:
I spend the 2017 Christmas holidays building this Arduino controlled Skittles colors sorter.

The machine is not working perfectly yet (see video). It has a color sorting success rate of about 95 % and has some feeder jamming problems.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LJ5PrK7l80&t=2s

Still... I think this is a pretty cool device and it made me learn a lot of stuff about design and C++ Arduino coding. It took about 40 hours to print all the parts on my Prusa I3 clone.

The Arduino script is available on GitHub: https://github.com/MxBoud/Arduino-Skittles-Sorter.

List of non-plastic parts used:

  • Color sensor : OSEPP Color Sensor (https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B00VDKVODS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

  • Stepper motor and driver : Kuman Stepper motor 28BYJ-48 ULN2003 5V (https://www.amazon.ca/Kuman-Stepper-arduino-28BYJ-48-Breadboard/dp/B01IP2R0CU/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1518648406&sr=1-3&keywords=arduino+stepper+motor)

  • Servo motor : Regular Arduino servo motors (https://www.amazon.ca/RioRand®-Micro-Servo-Airplane-Genuine/dp/B00M8RGGFG/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1518648482&sr=1-1&keywords=arduino+servo).

  • Bearing : Universal standard size 8x22x7w.

  • Screws and nut : Various length M3.

Design improvement list:

  • The holes on the Arduino connector part are not properly aligned.

Prusa

remixed_from.author: pemic
remixed_from.title: Coldend / Hotend Fan Holder Tevo Tornado

title: Tevo Tornado Coldend / Hotend Fan Holder Remix

description.text:
Thanks to pemic for sharing his original design :)
Since I wanted to reuse the hotend mount screws to hold the fan mount, I did a little remix of his file.
On the way I thougt it would also be nice to have the Tevo Logo in the fan cover :)

You will be able to screw the fan holder to the hotend by using the stock screws, I additionally secured them on with a little blue loctite, so they won't come loose over time.

To mount the hotend fan you can use 3mm screws, I even used a "tap and die" to cut the 3mm thread into the mount, but it should work without cutting a thread, too.
I happened to have the exact same screws that Tevo used for the hotend mount and they fit perfectly for mounting the hotend fan and the fan cover.

To mount the radial part cooling fan you can use the stock screws as well, the 2 longer ones on the bottom and one of the shorter ones on the top, but here you might need some kind of spacer, since the screw will now push against the hotend fan and cannot be screwed in completely.
So you can either use a spacer (I happened to have a nut that fits perfectly, you could also use a scrap piece of bowden tube) or cut down the screw in length, but I wanted to avoid that in case I want to go back to stock configuration again.

Pemic had two versions in his original design for the part cooling holder, I also made 2, one being slightly higher than the other (which I need to use on my Tornado)

Depending on the part cooling duct you use and if you use the original print bed, you might run into problems when homing, since the part is exactly on top of the screw head of the print bed, so watchout for that.

Update: I might be adding an additional screw option on the lower end of the hotend fan holder, similar to the original design, that screws inbetween the hotend cooling ribs, it might not be necessary, but I have just bent accidentially the uper two lashes the fan is no longer flush to the hotend ribs and the part cooling duct is touching the print bed on one end :(

Update 02-Jan-2018: I added a beefed up version of the hotend fan mount, so it won't bend that easy anymore. If anyone encounters problems even with the beefed up one, please let me know. Also check the last picture, by twisting the both fan cables two times around each other I avoid the part cooling fan cable to be too close to the x-axis, where it could wear out over time.

Tevo Tornado

No

0.2

100%

I chose 100% infill just to make sure everything is stable enough, lower infill might work, too.

description.text:
I have a Taz 4/5 and a Taz 6. I made a top mounted spool holded for my Taz 6 and found the the slots in the 2020 extrusions were 5mm instead of the 6mm wide on the older model.
I have metal T-nuts I bought on Amazon, but they are 6mm wide. I tried grinding them down.
Did not work too well. So I designed some 5 mm wide t-nuts for M3 screws which worked OK.
I made some out of PLA, PETg, and ABS. I used an M3 tap on most but you can get away with just using a screw to cut the threads. I have also included some 6mm wide designs for M3 and M4 screws. I definitely recommend using a tap on the M4 ones to prevent splitting.
Use a fine layer height. I used .15mm with a .5 nozzle on Taz and .4 nozzle on my new Prusa I3 MK3. I would always go for metal t-nuts if you have them. Using inserts in something this small does not work great. If you don't over crank the screws, the plastic ones work okay. Use washers. Make sure the screws do not bottom out in the extrusion.
I have not seen any metal insert t-nuts for the 5mm wide slots except for the flat ones requiring end plates or corners to be removed.
I hope someone uses this design and makes some metal ones!

title: Simple GameCube Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Need a way to easily mount your GameCube to a wall (or something other)? Then this simple wall mount could be the right thing to put on your printing list. The mount is more stable than it looks; even plugging / unplugging a controller or a memory card is no problem and doesn't move the cube.

About:
The GameCube's weight is carried by two cones that go into the holes on the back of the device. The two clamps prevent it from falling off.
To support the bottom of the cube, I added a weird looking shape.

You can use it as a permanent mount or just to put it away when you don't play, as you can easily take the GameCube from the wall by pushing the clamps up a bit.

This version will not work with the Game Boy Player attached.

Use whatever screw type (and maybe wall plugs) that fit your wall the best. I'm not responsible if your GameCube falls off and gets damaged.

Other mounts for Nintendo consoles I designed:

  • Simple N64 Wall Mount
  • Simple GameCube Wall Mount
  • Wii Wall Mount

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The STL file is for mounting the GameCube to a right wall (from front view). For left walls, you can mirror the model on the x or y axis (I didn't test it, but it's possible that the front clamp will partially cover the power button when mountet left).

Print with the wall facing part down and generate supports for the clamps for best detail (the cones must not be misshapen, else you can't push the GameCube all the way to the "back-plate").

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle in PLA with two outlines for the walls (seems to be stable enough).
The screw holes in this model are for 3mm screws with a countersunk head.

description.text:
This is a 10 turn helical antenna for 5.8GHz video receiver. There are plenty of youtube tutorials and websites which outline the build process so I won't document the build process. Here is a list of the other parts you'll need:

  • 1.6mm solid copper wire
  • Copper coated PC Board I cut it with my mini table saw (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1708586).
  • Coax wire and SMA connector or PCB SMA connector

I printed mine in ABS and used CA glue to hold it all together. I built mine as a RH antenna but I'm pretty sure you could build it as a LH antenna just by flipping one of the frames 180 deg. It's been successfully tested beyond 7km.

Update - Jan 2, 2019
I just realized "Helical 10 Turn - B.stl" was missing a hole, I've updated the STL file. If you printed the previous one, just drill the needed hole.

remixed_from.author: RandomFactoid

title: Kossel Mini Magball Effector with PCB Mount

description.text:
This Kossel Mini effector is a slight remix of Lauman’s Super simple upgraded Kossel Mini effector, combined with the main body changes from RandomFactoid’s remix, along with a modification of the top collar to hold the Think3DPrint3D wiring harness PCB. I'm using the magballs and rods from Haydn Huntley: http://www.magballarms.com

I’m only including the STL here for the modified piece, and direct you to the two upstream projects for the rest of the components.

The assembly instructions provided by Lauman are excellent. I did create a more detailed Bill of Materials (BOM) for the required hardware:

  • Hardware BOM:
    -- Magballs: (6)
    -- Magball nuts 3mm (6)
    -- Cooling vent bolts (8mmx3mm) (3) ((4) if not using dc42 IR probe)
    -- Fan attachments (10mmx3mm) (12 - but I only used 2 per fan for total of 6)
    -- Attaching collar to body (8mmx3mm) (3)
    -- Collar attachments (10mmx3mm) (2)
    -- Collar attachment nuts (3mm) (2)
    -- dc42 IR board attachment (2.5mm self-tapping) (2)
    -- dc42/T3P3 PCB attachment (2.5mm self-tapping) (2)
    --- Totals:
    ----- 10x3mm (14) (if populating all 3 fans with 4 bolts, otherwise (8)
    ----- 8x3mm (7) (if using dc42 IR probe, otherwise (6))
    ----- 3mm nuts (8) (if using Haydn magball studs, otherwise (2))
    ----- 2.5mm self-tapping screws (4) (if using T3P3 PCB, otherwise (2))

The magnets in Haydn's rods are strong enough to keep the fan blades from spinning, or to even stop them after they start spinning. Flipping the rods can help. I am also investigating shielding for the rod-ends.

Designed for the use as a starfighter, it's armorment makes it count as a capital ship to some scanners, and it flies on a large base.

Print in spiral mode, 4 or 5 bottom layers and no top layers. Don't print too fast. If you are having problems, set up as for spiral mode, but use 2 outer walls. That is especially useful when you are using Pause to change filament colors. Pausing on the inner wall will help conceal the change.

Idea? Then why are there photos?
Yes the model is solid, so you have to either "spiralize" or manually set the layer parameters.
The fourth photo above shows that it is printed using "vase mode" (that's S3D for what you call spriralized, corkscrew, etc.).
In Simplify 3D when using single wall mode vase you still have to turn off the top layers (top layers=0).
Or you can stop (in the process settings) at the layer or height before it prints the top layers.
If you still want a two (or more) outline wall, then turn off spiralize and manually set bottom layers to 3-5, and top to zero layers and sidewalls to 2 outlines.
comments.author: RomulusCreative

comments.text: If your run Spiralize in cura no matter what you do it will over ride and just make thin walls.. It wasnt an insult its an interesting idea as in the form of the design.. Somehow you took that as an insult.
comments.author: jaln

comments.text:
Not insulted.
Maybe you need a .5 or .6 nozzle?
When you use Vase/Corkscrew/Spiralize they always make one outer wall and no fill. You cannot spiral if you have two walls.

title: Axel's 3D printed quadcopter V2(carbon fibre arms)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is version 2 of my 3D printed quadcopter with carbon fibre arms. It is a complete remake of my old design using Autodesk Inventor instead of SketchUp. This one is made for 14 mm diameter carbon fibre tubes, and is a lot more durable and also looks better due to all plastic parts having more rounded shapes.

Version 1 is still available here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2427724

This quadcopter is designed mainly for LOS (Line Of Sight) flying, but it can of course also be flown FPV. I have also included multiple fixed FPV camera mounts, and also an adjustable model. There are also other extra parts for mounting 5 mm LEDs, antennas and cables. The bigger version of the cable clamp can be used to clamp over the SMA connector on almost any FPV video transmitters.

I used 14 mm carbon fibre tubes that I got from Hobbyking.
Link: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/carbon-fiber-round-tubes-14-12-500mm.html

The carbon fibre tubes come in lengths of 500mm, I usually cut them into 3 pieces, about 166 mm each. I have also tried cutting them into 4 pieces, giving me 125 mm long arms. Shorter arms are perfect for FPV since it makes the quad slightly more durable. Longer arms are better for LOS flying since it makes the quad easier to see.

When assembling the quadcopter frame, dry fit all parts and make sure everything fits as intended. The inside of the plastic parts may need to be sanded slightly for the carbon fibre tubes to fit. I use a "sanding cylinder" on a rotary tool for this. Start by glueing the motor mounts to the carbon fibre tubes. Then glue the arms to the main baseplate, while keeping the entire assembly upside down on a flat surface to make it straight and square. Use CA glue. The rest of the parts, including spacers and top plate, as well as extra parts, are attached using 10mm long M3 screws. many extra parts have the same hole spacing (20 mm), making it possible to assemble the quadcopter in many different configurations depending on your needs.

Assembly video of the older version of this quadcopter. The same methods apply:
https://youtu.be/8wl7gxEV0Ps

Flight video (of an older version of this quadcopter):
https://youtu.be/eP1WFb1E-70

My setup:

  • Motors: Racerstar Racing Edition 2205 2300KV
  • ESCs: Racerstar 20A BLHELI_S OPTO
  • Flight controller: Omnibus F4 V2 PRO with Built-in 5V BEC and current sensor
  • Battery: LiPo 3 cell 2200mAh
  • Propellers: 6x4 Kingkong

Update 2018-02-28
updated this page with new Images of the real quadcopter, All 3D files are the same.

Printer:

Homebuilt CoreXY printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15 mm layer height, 0.4 mm nozzle

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The baseplate is the part that breaks first. Make it as strong as possible by setting top/bottom thickness to something very high, this will ensure it is printed solid. Use around 3-5 shell layers and 30-50% infill on all other parts. Infill is not very critical since almost no parts have large volumes.

Use rafts or brims if you know that you need it. It depends a lot on your printer.

remixed_from.title: Aluminatus Corner Clamps With Height Adjuster & 1mm taller clamps

title: Aluminatus Corner Clamps With Height Adjuster & Glass Clamps

description.text:
This is a new version of the bed corner plates and also clamps to actually hold the glass down. The works in conjuction with my center support if you need to pull a bow out of the glass, but it also helps keep the glass and spreader down if you have a flat glass. Since the heat spreader and glass are stacked on the corners they may want to move a little or not land in the exact same height when taken off and reinstalled. This pulls them down and holds them better. These bed corners use the same side pieces as the other bed corners (F-300 and A-300). The side pieces that move (A-300) are just barely snugged just to hold the glass in perfect place. These are not intended to actually clamp the glass in tension. The new hold down clamps take care of that.

See:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101807
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2740345

These use the same hardware except there is an added M5 for the corner clamps. This gets snugged so there is just a little resistance. You can spin them out of the way to remove the glass. You can also move the adjusters up and down with the clamps in place. They should spring enough to allow precise adjustment of the corner heights.

I print them in ABS. I used .2mm layer and 20-30% infill. The screws that go into plastic only should thread themselves with just a little pressure and provide enough resistance to stay put when adjusted.

author: eozzy

title: Large Bender Piggy Bank for Creality CR-10 and other large printers

description.text:
I remixed this bust into a bank as part of my YouTube review of the Creality CR-10 (https://youtu.be/FPgnjmNCEak). I was sort of inspired by Joel Telling the 3D Printing Nerd, who printed an upsized version of the bust and cut a hole in it to make it a bank. Instead of doing that, I wanted to incorporate the coin slot and plug in the bottom.

It has been scaled up to fit the CR-10 or similarly large printers (at least 400mm vertical build volume). It does NOT require any support material, but I think it should be printed with at least 10% infill and enough top and bottom layers to ensure that the top of his head comes together without any holes (maybe 4 depending on layer height). The other settings are up to you, but I probably wouldn't go too low on the layer height or it will take forever to print. The cap/plug on the bottom might be a little tight depending on your printer's tolerances.

comments.text: You mention infill of 10%. Is that inside the walls? Otherwise money won't go in?
comments.author: tubbers

comments.text: Yes, in between the inner and outer walls. Just selecting it in the slicer should be fine. The point is that you shouldn't choose 0% infill or you'll end up with one shell inside another with nothing to bind them together.

title: Magball Carriages for Kossel printer with 2020 extrusions

description.text:
These carriages are a remix from Haydn Huntley’s carriages for 2020 extrusions. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183355

The magballs and precision-built the carbon fiber, zero-backlash, magnetic arms are available from Haydn Huntley’s website: http://www.MagBallArms.com

The primary change is to use the 15mm Delrin V-roller wheels from Think3DPrint3D, which best fit onto 3mm M3 bolts. https://www.think3dprint3d.com/deltaprinter-parts/V-roller I’ve also added a spot for 2.5 bolt to be used as an end-stop trigger.

These carriages have 45mm rod spacing, to use with the effector below: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2741790

Per carriage, you will need:

3 of the above V roller wheels.
3 M3x25 bolts
6 M3 flat washers
3 M3 nyloc nuts to secure the three axles.
2 3/8" ball studs (from Haydn Huntley - see above).
2 M3 nyloc nuts to secure the ball studs.
2 M3x35 SHCS for the belt tightener.
2 M3 nuts for the belt tightener.
1 M3x35 SHCS for preloading the carriage wheels
1 M3 nyloc nut for preloading the carriage wheels
1 M3x20 SHCS for the vertical post for the lower G2 belt attachment
1 M3x12 bolt for upper G2 belt attachment
1 M3 nyloc nut for upper G2 belt attachment
2 M3 nuts for the vertical post
1 M3 washer for the vertical post
1 M3 nut to secure the vertical post
1 M2.5x12 hex for end-stop trigger

Assembly order is as follows:

M3 25mm bolt

For each of 2 magballs
magball

comments.author: Laeffe

comments.text: Maybe I'm just not experienced enough to be trying this design, but I can't seem to figure out how to get the internal supports out of the tubes so the air will blow through. I understand that S3D produces better supports that aren't as firmly attached to the model, but I don't seem to be having much luck with it--adhesion issues and such. Thoughts?
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: If your using Cura check the box that says supports from build platform only, it will work fine.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: If you are using S3D you can generate automatic supports or do them manually. If you do automatic, it will place them where it thinks they should be, like inside the ducts. If you do them manually you can place the supports where you want. I used 8mm supports under the majority of where you need them and 4mm supports to fill in the gaps or in smaller places. If your having adhesion problems in S3D, under the supports tab you can tell it you want 1 or 2 base layers. That will make a solid base layer for the support to grow off, you could also increase the support infill percentage to make a more dense support.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: Yeah, that helped a lot, as a matter of fact.
comments.author: kevinb22

comments.text: Not a problem, and sorry to hear about not getting all the hardware with your printer..... If you can please post back and let me know how it fits and works for you.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: Well, rats! I like this cooler a lot. Don't have a fan to run it yet, but I think the design is clever and well considered. I bolted it onto the shuttle, and the reach of the ducts is a little short of where I imagine I want it to be. Instead of sitting at either side of the nozzle, it's about 12 mm behind it; and it hangs a little too low as well, maybe 5-6 mm lower than the nozzle itself. Now, I have to be fair, this is a PowerSpec Bi3Plus, not a Maker Select, so it was a roll of the dice whether it would fit, so that's not a complaint by any means. I'm just disappointed that my machine isn't close enough that it would work for me.
comments.author: kevinb22

comments.text: Ill mod it for you if you can give me specs, don't worry ill make it work for you. I didn't know you had a PowerSpec. Dimensions must be different. I can make it for you.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: i have a power spec as well, what orientation are you pingthing this on? all you need for this is to remove the back cover (the cooler has a cover built in) make sure support are on Print bed only and use the same screws of the back cover to mount the cooler.
comments.author: kevinb22

comments.text: I did remove the back cover and replace it with the model. It fits perfectly. But that positions the outlets of the ducts a little too far back and too far down from the nozzle.When I get a chance in 10 hours or so, I'll post a photo, if I can take one that illustrates the issue. @kevinb22, I will be glad to give you whatever dimensions are needed to develop a model that fits my printer, if you're open to doing so. I don't want to put you in a position of feeling obligated to make a ton of one-off mods for each user with a slightly different configuration, though.
comments.author: JuniorGamingTime

comments.text: You can't tell from either of these photos, but it appears that the plate onto which the back cover--or this model--gets bolted is about 10 degrees away from plumb. I can't say for sure, but maybe if it were bent back to nearly plumb, the ducts would be at the right z-height. I'm confident they'd still be short of being centered on the nozzle.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: Ill make it work for you. If you back plate is bent, then that would bring it to the right height it looks like. But no point in bending your plate, if I need to make adjustments anyway Ill just raise them up. Ill just estimate from your photos and we can go from there. Its going to be all guess work for me, but I'm up for it. It looks like it has to move a touch to the right for you as well. I don't get why JuniorGamingTime lined up perfect on his powerspec and yours is way off though.
comments.author: 3dward_4nderson

comments.text: I don't know that the back plate is bent--it may just be that production values are sufficiently sloppy that you get a wide variation of geometries that still manage to print well enough for a sub-$500 device.

remixed_from.author: joaopedro
remixed_from.title: My Customized Prusa i3 Flexible Z Coupling

title: K8200/3drag z-axis leadscrew flexible motor coupler

description.text:
Spring coupler with 5mm and 8mm shaft diameters Based on parametric scad (file included)
A remix of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:268468 Made out of desperation until I get a metal one!

There is not much clearance with the motor mount bolts so you need to trim the M3 screws with a file or grinder. If you put 3*M3 nuts onto the screw it gives about the right depth. The scad produces a non manifold output but it slices ok at the given settings. If you change a setting then check your slice before printing. The included stl slices ok. If you modify the scad, the largest bore diameter must be the #2 diameter which is at the bottom. 5mm shaft needed drilling out a little to clean it up.
The M3 nuts are slightly loose in the holes. Repetier 0.9
No support required :-)
190C 55C PLA
2mm brim
0.3mm layers
25% honeycomb infill
70mm/s fill
40mm/s perimeters
30mm/s outer and tight perimeters
200mm/s acceleration About 30mins to print

comments.text: what are the od of the part and with the screws? looks great
comments.author: jt11racin

comments.text: I don't know.  I scrapped the printer and part a year ago.  You might find the od in the scad source.
comments.author: jt11racin

comments.text: best thing ever, I was having problems because the original coupler that came with my kit was not drilled truely, causing the z axis to wobble a lot. It was causing problems with every 3rd or 4th layer being not as tall resulting in excess material getting pushed out the sides. I printed this coupler (with ABS because I ran out of PLA) and now there is no wobble! Just doing a test print now to see the results.

title: Ormerod Parts Cooling Fan Mount - E3D hotend

description.text:
After upgrading my Ormerod to an E3D V6Lite hotend using markdoll01's E3D mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1005956), I found that I couldn't get the fan duct with his design to print on any printer I had available - the overhangs were just a little too much, and the walls too thin, so instead I created this.

This bolts on the outside of the head cooling fan, with a 40mm fan mounted on top of the recess in the body for parts cooling - with my E32D hotend the duct comes out about 1.5mm above the printbed, below the heater block but bang in line with the nozzle and extruded filament.

description.text:
I have owned a FLSUN Kossel for a while now, and finally managed to create a workflow that allowed me to use it without spending hours recalibrating it! I've now got about 400 hours on the printer, and noticed that the belts were fraying at the top pulleys, on closer inspection the belts are being pulled across towards the center of the printer and riding over the bearings that act as pulleys. There are two reasons for this, the brackets are being pulled down towards the center of the bed by the tension on the belt (I overtensioned them on the initial build..), but also my FLSUN has the linear rails, which brings the belts more towards the center of the printer than the original carriages. The stock brackets don't have enough adjustment on my printer to cope.

The other aspect I wanted to fix is that to tension the belts requires moving the top frame, I wanted to separate out the tension in the belts from the actual frame dimensions.

So this design is my first attempt resolving these issues:

  1. Belts ride on proper 20t pulleys
  2. Belts are tensioned separately from the frame
  3. Frame can be dimensioned accurately and tightened.
  4. Belts can adjust over a wide range of positions depending on where they actually ride on the printer

I wanted to thank mming1106 who designed and uploaded the original corners.

13th Jan 2018 - Revised the STL as for some reason one of the parts was sitting about 0.05mm off the print bed which looked OK but refused to print reliably... Still learning!.

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I used my Tronxy X1 for this print as its still running....

After you print the pieces, assembly is as shown. I used m2.5 6mm screws to mount the top hat on to the frame. These just thread into the plastic. The tensioner bolt is just an m3 30mm cap head, and a nylock lock nut on the other end.
The pully is a 20t M3 pulley with a 30mm (I think ) m3 cap head bolt, this just threads into the plastic on the other side of the frame.

Designed and built in TinkerCad!

The reason that the frame has the top hat section separate, is that my tronxy is not great at bridging, so by separating it I avoided the need for support material, and also bridging. (And actually this makes the printer easier to reassemble.

comments.text: Installed 2 out of the three corners on my FLSUN,  have done 25 hours of printing so far.  It's looking good. One possible issue is that the pulley is free to rotate,  in practice this does not change the tension on the belt, but II guess it's possible it might cause the belt to stick in the carriage.  Might look at a more guided pulley holder.  Also since the upper frame is now fixed in place it's possible to add some bracing so I might look at that in the next iteration too,   but even with this mod II can pick the printer up by one corner and not have any layer shifting, I'm pretty happy with that.

title: Galaxy Note 3 Stand (adjustable stand)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this Stand to use my old "Samsung Galaxy Note 3" as a Webcam.

It can be mounted on a printer frame or wherever you want it and can be adjusted in 2 Axis (left and right, up and down)!

The really cool thing about it, you don't have to assemble anything. You can print it already assembled.

IMPORTANT:

The moving parts are only working 100% when your printer is properly calibrated and when you print it at <= 0.1mm Layerheight.

After the print, you need to apply some force to break the little-glued spots to get it moving. I used some pliers and a bench vice to get it done.

This is Version 3 and I might adjust some minor things in the future. It works great for me. Might need to implement some stoppers in the "lateral axis" it will get loose after a lot of adjustments. (Might pretty depend on material / print-settings etc...)

comments.author: Tuskawilla

description.text:
This is a mount to allow a BLTouch to be used with an Ormerod printer.

This object requires the Ormerod 2 E3D v^ Hotend Mount with Fan mount to be installed (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1005956).

This object uses the fan mounting bracket on the mount to attach to the printer, and when installed with an M3x15 screw is rigidly attached to the print head.

Wiring the BLTouch to the Duet 0.6 controller on the Ormerod is as follows:

Red wire to Pin 1 on the expansion header
Brown wire to Pin 2 on the expansion header
Orange wire to Pin 31 on the expansion header.

Black and White need to be connected to "GND" and "IN" on the E0 endstop connector - they will not work anywhere else.

GCode is:

In config.g

M307 H3 A-1 C-1 D-1 ; Release the heater pin to be used to control the BLTouch servo
M558 P4 X0 Y0 Z1 H5 F100 T2000 ; set the Z-proble to mode 4
M574 Z1 S1 '; set the Z stop to Active High
M557 X10:140 Y10:180 S20 ; Set up bed mesh levelling to probe between X10 and 140, and Y10- and 180 on a 20mm centre - this allows you to just select "Run Mesh Grid Compensation" and the printer will automatically run it.

In bed.g
M561
G1 Z10 F200
G1 X1 Y1 F2000
G30 P0 Z-100000
G1 Z10 F200
G1 X1 Y180 F2000
G30 P1 Z-100000
G1 Z10 F200
G1 X140 Y180 F2000
G30 P2 S Z-100000
G1 Z10 F200
G1 X140 Y1 F2000
G30 P3 Z-100000
G1 Z10 F200
G1 X70 Y90 F2000
G30 P4 Z-100000 S5
G4 P1500 ; Leave the probe there to give the web interface time to report the plane points
G1 Z10 F200

This will allow you to run G29 automatic bed compensation - I have my slicer profiles set to run this before every print - it takes about 45 seconds.

Make sure that any M557a are removed from homex.g, homey.g and homez.g

homez.g should read something like:

G91 ; set movements relative
G1 Z5 F200 ; move upwards 5mm at 200 mm/min to make sure we don't hit anything
G90 ; set movements absolute
G1 X1 Y1 ; Move to the X, Y point at which to probe the bed over the paper
G30 ; Move down until the probe is triggered (i.e. move down until the IR voltage is 590, which automatically sets Z = 2.3mm).
G1 Z10 F2000 ; Move down to Z=0 (i.e. move down the last 2mm)

I also have a "deployprobe.g" which reads:

M280 P3 S160 I1 ; reset the probe in case it has faulted
G4 P450 ; wait 450ms for probe to reset
M280 P3 S10 I1 ; deploy probe
G4 P75 ; wait 75ms

and a "retractprobe.g" which reads

M280 P3 S90 I1 ; retract BLTouch probe

Capot moteur pour Piper J3 (Buissyne)
Dessiné par Moi Michel Therreau

title: Airwolf V2 for 250 sized RC Heli

description.text:
Firstly i give full credits to user Marten from whom i pinched this model from.

https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/1c76ab323298a4176f0b1d884aa8c15c/Airwolf-v20

V2 , chopped and cleaned quite a bit, the original had a few areas that needed cleaning up , for a computerized illustration it wasnt a problem but for an actual 3d real-world model it needed some serious hitting with a hammer to try and get everything to print as it should.

The windows are meant to be cut out and i will upload the "plug"s you will use to make the inserts by using heat to shrink an old coke bottle over a mold.

There are of course extra bits , the weapon pods and turbine details will be uploaded shortly and anything else that goes along with it.

I am trying to find a good configuration of parts so that this can be printed in vase mode and then glued together to create the overall Airwolf aesthetic. The front piece can be printed in vase mode as is but the two central halves have issues at the front of the turbine intakes and the heavy curve around the weapons pod, this is obviously cured when not in vase mode by adding supports and extra perimeters.

What I need to learn : I need a print mode that will print a single walled shell that has a honeycomb backing to a defineable depth, IE a single perimeter with a variable depth support. I know using simplify I can change the infill % through layering in defined splits to allow me to change the infill and perimeters across sections of the model but I haven't figured out how to make the infill work the way that I want it to.

Things for V3 : adapt fuselage to include mounts to hold the servo's, main shaft and various other parts negating the need for the 250 carbon frame

description.text:
This is a remix of two different models:

  • Nazzaf's: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1198514
  • Barspin: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:113764

Barspin's frame held the camera nice and tight but made it difficult to insert and remove the GoPro camera and did not have the openings correctly placed for the Hero 3+ mics. Nazzaf's frame made it easy to insert and remove the camera, had the openings placed correctly for Hero 3+ mics, and had bigger holes for the buttons (which I liked since I would be using this while skiing with thick gloves). However, the camera did not fit in the frame tightly and would rattle.

I took both of the best aspects of each of these designs and put them together while also allowing spacing to mount the GoPro protective lens (https://www.amazon.com/GoPro-Protective-Lens-Official-Accessory/dp/B00F19Q3T2) which I always use when running my GoPro in with a frame housing.

EDIT: I modified the stl a bit to make the frame more sturdy and less flexible. I basically removed one of the clips and made the remaining clips shorter. Therefore, the current stl file will not look exactly like the frame shown in the pictures. It will have three clips instead of four.

title: Small Dessicant Box with Sliding Lid and Catch

description.text:
Small desiccant box measuring 56mm x 56mm x 26mm. Lid slides on via dovetail joint, and has catch to lock closed (but can be reopened with a little effort). Air slots are 1mm wide.

The sliding dovetail requires a reasonably well-calibrated printer. If your printer is over-extruding, it may be too tight.

Sketchup design file included for those who want to change the design.

Silica-gel desiccant can be regenerated by baking at 75-90C (167-200F) for a few hours. Since PLA may soften at that temperature, I recommend a higher temperature filament (I used clear PETG.) If you use PLA, you will want to open the box and pour the desiccant into a baking pan for the oven, then return to the box after cooling a bit.

title: Glue stick holder for Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Monoprice Maker Select
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have the Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1 (same as the Monoprice Maker Select) and I use glue sticks on top of my glass bed. I normally buy them from Amazon and keep them in the box.

I decided that I should use the extra space on top of the control box to hold the glue sticks, an anti bounce hammer I use to remove prints from the print bed and a deburring tool. This attaches to the control box with a 5 mm bolt.

I have included the Fusion 360 file so anyone can edit the file to match the sizes they need. You can also post a comment for what you need and I will change it for you. I have also included a little tester for the mounting holes. That way you don't have to print out the whole unit and then find out the holes are too far / close together. I don't know if other versions of this printer have different mounting holes.

The glue sticks are 0.77 oz sized and are around 26 mm in diameter.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000U6FJQE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The anti bounce hammer is around 52 mm x 30 mm.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1947157

The deburring tool is around 26 mm in diameter. It is by the Plastic Processing Equipment but I can't find which item it is.
http://www.ppe.com/
I think it is the item on the bottom left here (heavy duty rout-a-burr)
http://www.ppe.com/content/Flipbook/17cat/ppe.html#p=206

I purchased the bolts from Trimcraft and they are 5 mm by 8 mm long:
https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=442&search=SCS-M5-8

Filament is Maker Geeks Raptor PLA "In the Army Now":
https://www.makergeeks.com/collections/raptor-series-pla/products/raptor-series-pla-high-performance-3d-filament-in-the-army-now-green-175mm-1kg

title: Unistrut Strut Channel Mount for Sabrent HB-UMA7 USB Hub w/ Printed M4 Strut Channel Nut

description.text:
I use a grid of strut channel (superstrut brand from Home Depot) on my home office wall for mounting a grid of monitors. I also have too many USB devices connected to my computer, most of which are not used most of the time. I bought a few of these hubs which have switches for each port to solve that problem, and designed these mounts to conveniently affix the hubs to the struts on the wall.

You can use any standard strut channel nut with this, but I included the stl file for the printed nuts I use with these since there is very little load on them and I didn't want to waste "real" nuts on these. This part uses my company's M4 threaded inserts which you can buy on amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/initeq-M4-0-7-Threaded-Inserts-Printing/dp/B07453HQZ8/

title: Printrbot Simple Aluminum Extruder 40mm Fan mount 2013/2014
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Fan Mount is designed for the 2014 Simple's Aluminum Extruder. It will require a 12v-dc 40mm Fan as well. It also fits the 2013 with aluminum Direct Drive extruder upgrade w/plate.
The 2013 Model Has the zip-tie almost in the center of the mount. The 2014 Has the zip-tie closer to the rear of the extruder mounting plate.
It is designed to fit precisely on the 5.8mm Wood Extruder mount. It requires a little force to apply it since it is a compression fit. I would suggest removing your extruder mount in order to install it.
Another hint, install the zip tie loosely, before installing the fan mount. It is extremely small area and you may have trouble trying to connect a zip-tie after it is installed. Be sure to let it cool completely so it is not expanded /warm before installing.
I printed it using 0.25 layer height and only using 2 perimeters. As with all custom parts, you may need to modify the part or print to make it fit your machine.

The 2013 Model Has the zip-tie almost in the center of the mount. The 2014 Has the zip-tie closer to the rear of the extruder mounting plate.
It is designed to fit precisely on the 5.8mm Wood Extruder mount. It requires a little force to apply it since it is a compression fit. I would suggest removing your extruder mount in order to install it.
Another hint, install the zip tie loosely, before installing the fan. see description for more info

comments.text: I have a question. How did you get the ptfe tube through the roller without pinching the tube, and stopping the filament from going through?
comments.author: bbrown1951

comments.text:
I had a sampler pack from JT&T products, it includes several sizes, including thin walled version that fits precisely.
You are probably more familiar with the thick version that is commonly used for feed tube on a bowden style extruder. If you have one that is too large to fit, you may be able to split it with a razor knife and remove a small vertical section so that it would fit the hole. Since it is being used as a guide, that should work and remain in position. It should fit freely instead of compressing it to fit this extruder's hole.
If you look closely at the picture, you will notice there is 2 pieces of ptfe. The second one is slightly larger and does not go through the hole. It holds the smaller one in place, (before the roller). So it guides the filament. You could also trime the part against the roller and leave the ptfe guide touching bottom as well.
comments.author: bbrown1951

comments.text: I only have the standard PTFE tube. It has a 2mm ID and a 4mm OD. So my thick PTFE would not allow the filament to pass inside the PTFE where it is pinched by the roller. The extruder has to pinch the filament to move it into the hotend.

title: Oversized knob for Good Cook Salad Spinner

description.text:
The knob on our salad spinner broke off a while back and we needed a new one. The first version was much smaller, but it fit. When I went to find a picture of the original product online, I saw that the knob was larger than the one I'd designed, so, I measured it based on the base and in a brain fart, forgot to divide my measure in half (radius vs diameter), and made the radius 2x what it should be, exported the STL, sent it to print, and went to bed.

In a Bob Ross happy little accident, it still fits, still works, and we kinda like the bigger knob anyways, so, here it is.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used 4 walls, 4 bottom layers, and 4 top layers, to make sure it was strong enough, this gave the legs close to 100% equiv infill, but they were all walls.

When you load up the model, you'll notice that it is laying on its side, that is by design. In order for the legs that snap into the base to not snap off between layers, I re-oriented it to print this way, with supports. It does leave some artifacts on the outer dome, but those can be sanded off if you want a prettier final product.

In FreeCAD, starting with the sketch workspace, I drew out half the profile, set all the constraints based on caliper measurements of the hole it was fitting into, then did a revolve in the Part Design. I then made another sketch in the shape of the block I wanted to cut-out to the middle of the center to make the legs, padded and removed, then two more smaller blocks to cut off the edges of the feet so it would fit nicely into the hole it mounts into.

author: monkeyboy417

print_settings.Notes:: I suggest horizontal printing as vertical printing makes them too weak to stand up to use.  With horizonal orientation, I had a fair amount of trouble getting these to stay adhered to the bed even with supports and a brim.  The larger ones worked ok but the smaller ones peeled off.  I had good success making a square as shown in the picture.  This probably balances out some of the cooling stress.  I elevated the larger ones by 1mm and the smaller ones by 2mm and then let Simplify 3d apply auto supports.   I also used a 10 layer attached skirt.  After printing, little light sanding on the ends is all they needed.  In white, they look a little like string cheese.

print_settings.Notes:: Should be printed design up with raft and support for best results.

description.text:
This leather stamp was designed after the Crafttool branded leather working stamp kit and is tested working with the Craftool Hefty Handle 8197-00. If you do not have a Hefty Handle applying pressure directly at the center of the stamp and striking it will work. Try not to strike the stamp with a mallet as it will not last very long.

How do I use it?

  1. Import STL into program of choice and create design. Remember you must mirror all of the design for it to appear right side up when stamped. (Tinkercad is what I used for the text design, Fusion 360 for the stamp design)

  2. The offset from the face of the stamp should be 2.60mm for it to be a good depth for leather stamping.

  3. Print with the design facing up for best result use rafts and supports to hold the stamp in place while it prints. You can print the design down against the bed but if you don't have perfect first layer adhesion you will make a mess of your design.

  4. Stamp away!

If you are not capable of creating your own STL's contact me and I will see what I can do. Tipping is always welcome for custom work ;-)

Thank you and enjoy.

author: Allvtec

description.text:
Keep that special someone on a leach… or use them as kinky accessories to your outfit.
The 2 parts lock together with M3x30 socket head screws and nut.
Although very durable when printed in PLA, they are breakable in case of emergency. Have fun, but keep is safe!

There are 3 versions:
One version is solid.
Two are designed to hold decorative M4x6 socket screws in a tapped M4 hole. One has printed through holes and one has inside holes. The last one prints nicer since the outside perimeter is printed in one part. The holes have to be drilled afterwards with a 3.2mm drill and tapped M4.

The 2 parts can be printed in one piece without support and seperated after printing. A gentle wiggle and pull on the hinges wil seperate the parts.

This is Titan with E3D V6 setup with Z adjustable mount for the BLTouch. Whit this approach you don't have to worry about setting the BLTouch Z height because you can move it freely to adjust the height that suitable for your condition.
The Titan mount has pole portruding quite tall I used to secure the wire to not dangling down and touching the bed or catching something then snap off.

The BLTouch mount using 1 x 4mm x 10mm Tnut and it's corresponding flathead bolt for locking the BLTouch position in place.
You need also 40mm fan and 4 x 3mm x 12mm bolts

All print already oriented at its best position to print
BLTouch offsets from the nozzle tip are X 26mm, Y -1mm

And don't forget to give brim around the base. Let it touch the part for string support againts lifting.

Creality CR10

description.text:
When installing my Ring Doorbell Pro, I wanted to find a good way to mount it in the exact same location as the doorbell button I was removing. I didn't want unnecessary holes or wire showing.

I had 2 issues - First, there was a thick bead of caulk in my mounting location. Second, I needed to get the Ring Doorbell out far enough so that the brick wasn't blocking its internal camera.

Just in case someone has the similar issues, I thought I'd upload this bracket. I also uploaded several variations of this bracket that would allow for mounting the Ring Pro on a corner.

If anyone is curious about the finish, it is Modern Masters Copper Paint ( http://a.co/hCX8B3w ) Patina'd with the Green solution ( http://a.co/hyjpopt ).

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Notes:

I printed with the Ring Mounting Location pointing up, and supports below the overhang.

I leave for work when it is still dark out early in the morning. When it snows overnight, it is sometimes a struggle without outdoor lights by the driveway to see when brushing snow off of my car. The other morning I was using my phone as a flashlight while trying to brush my car off, and I decided I needed a better solution.

First, I checked Amazon to see if they had a snow brush with LED's in it already, which they did: but they were a little too expensive for my liking.

Next I checked on here to see if someone else made a clip for a flashlight. I found this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67840

Then I searched for a snow brush clip. I found this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162377

I fused the two clips together on TinkerCAD, and here is the result!

Then I stole my husbands flashlight and ran outside to test it all out.. :) He knows he is not getting it back, haha. Sorry!

I can't wait for the next snowfall to try it out!

The flashlight clip is suspended in the center of the snow brush clip, so I did use some supports when I printed it.

author: EricGHanson

description.text:
UPDATE V2
(04.01.18) I added a little bit stronger Version.

I had a little bit trouble with big 2kg spool so I designed this addon.
This is an addon for an famoud spool holder. With this Addon you can use standard 608 bearings. You can adjust the distance on the holder.

ATTENTION: dont use low frisction bearing or your spool will turn further then you want!!!

For an 1kg spool you dont need "Ende2". Print instead of "Ende" twice.

You need for an 2kg spool

  • two M3x20 with hexnut
  • two 608 bearing
  • twice the "Mitte"
  • each one of "Ende" and "Ende2"

you need only support with the "Ende2".

print_settings.Notes:: These are tiny.  I used rafts and supports at 100% infill.  Consider scaling to 195% in the cross section to facilitate fit.  Scale the long axis to that of your base design.

description.text:
Harry Potter style Time Turner. You have the option of printing an immobile design in one piece or two. You can also print a mobile design. This was originally intended to be an ornament and so is only about 20mm across. It scales well to 200%. You may not get an intact print at 100% scale (see print settings). Most of the samples were printed using the rings without flanges. I added flanged rings but have only printed them using the mobile "print in place design"

I printed with a variety of filaments including petg, PLA, polysmooth, colorfab copper.

Notes:

Scaling

I use Simplify 3d to slice and I couldn't get it to fill the rings at 100% scale. This probably has to do with my nozzle dimeter of 0.4mm and extrusion width but I'm not sure. It would fill in at 110% scale. So the smallest items pictured are 110% scaled. I scaled all my mobile prints at 200% with modification for the hour glass and pins as below.

Infill

I used 100% infill on all prints scaled at 110%. I used 30% infill on larger single piece designs and the star piece for the mobile design. I used 100% infill for the rings and pins for the mobile design.

Hour glass

For designs with a separate hour glass, I printed in vase mode using a clear PETG for one and Polysmooth clear for another. For one piece designs, I printed using the same clear materials and then painted. For 200% scale prints, I printed the hour glass at 197% scale to provide a snug fit. I used an attached 10 shell skirt. If you print in vase mode, the hour glass will be fragile and you will have to carefully adjust your temperature and extrusion multipliers to get the best adhesion. You can see a few failed hour glasses in my picture.

Pins

These are tiny. I used rafts and supports at 100% infill. Consider scaling to 195% in the cross section to facilitate fit. Scale the long axis to that of your base design.

Non-mobile

If you print a non-mobile one piece design, printing in a clear material and then painting makes for a nice look. The gold painted large sample is a one piece made from petg. For two piece designs you can use a clear material for the hour glass and your preferred color for the body and rings.

Mobile

Print the hour glass clear and the rings and stars in your preferred material. I'd suggest using a drill bit to regularize the holes in the rings and the stars. You may have to sand the pin slightly.

Assembly

I used cyanoacrylate glue sparingly in the pin holes on the stars. You can do one side and then the other. The hour glass can be placed and then have a small amount of CA glue to hold it in place.

Print in place

I created a mobile design with flange and pins attached to the stars. This version printed well using 0.2 mm layer height. This may be the easiest to print if you do not want to mix and match material colors as it avoids gluing the pins.

title: AA Battery Insert Slugs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
AA Slug (Nail Pocket) is a sheath for a larger nail, to take the place of an AA battery when using non-1.5v replacements in a multi-battery pack. Simply takes up the space where one AA battery would go, in those cases where filling the battery bay would result in over-voltage (ex. using Lithium Ion batteries in place of alkaline, as LiIon runs 3.6v per cell). Simply shove an appropriate-sized nail through the slug, then cut off the end for the + post. (pictured)

AA Slug (AAA Pocket) is a sheath for using a AAA battery in an AA battery slot. Sometimes ya gotta make-do with that's on-hand. Does require a metal rod or hefty roll of foil to insert in the narrow opening to act as a contact between the battery and the electronic device. I use the off-cut portion of nail from the other slug. (not pictured as of this time)

May be possible to use large-gauge copper wire instead of nail if you have some handy.

This is a vertical garden created for those with not enough space.

You'll need a pallet or wooden slats to hold the parts.
There's a single mount that holds any size of vase (small, medium and big).
I design the vases like cubes because it's easier to print and have a modern look.
There is a hole template for mounts' distance for each vase size.

The automatic drip irrigation system is still being implemented but I already designed the hoses fixings. I used air systems tubing (PU) to distribute the water from a PET bottle (6mm ext and 4mm int) and the goal is to add a bigger reservoir on top of everything.
The drip control is from ggoss, Roller Clamp for Flexible Tubing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174398) and I added a roller with no axle so you can insert a metal axle (3mm axle to get interference), because the 3d printed one always break.
The flexible tubing (10 mm ext and 6mm int) goes very well with the PU tubing and can be very leak proof with some zip ties. You won't need much of the flexible tubing, which is more expensive than PU, since it just goes through the clamp body (~15 cm).
You should use one clamp for each vase because each plant has a good amount of water. The clamp body can be drilled to get fastened to the pallet.

  • No special printer settings.
  • The vases can be pretty hollow (10 to 12% infill).
  • I printed everything in PETG since it's going to get a lot of sun.

Will try some ABS in the future, but PETG gets leak proof with only 2 loops (vertical shell). Mounts and fixings can be printed many each time to improve printing time.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
These rails should fit the slide-in 3.5" racks found in Centurion PC cases. They will probably fit other manufacturers as well. No additional hardware is required, the pegs press-fit into the screw holes of 3.5" hard drives or 2.5"-to-3.5" adapter caddies, then slide into the hard drive rack.

Print with one of the narrow sides to the bed and use support for the pegs. If the pegs are a little rough after printing they should still fit the drive mounting holes. When you're ready to remove them, using a flat-headed screw driver makes it much easier to pop them off the drive.

title: Allen Key Socket Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Device to allow using regular allen wrenches on a 3/8" drive socket wrench/T-handle. This was done primarily as a thought and design exercise, as long-reach allen 3/8" drive wrenches are commonly available. As of this time, only a 2.5mm adapter is completed, as it was the only one I needed at the time. Will update with more in the future. Secures together using standard M3 screws and nuts. Size is rather large, to provide strength when turning higher torque loads and for turning by hand.

Filament costs pennies, while long-reach 3/8" drive allen wrenches cost dollars. ;)

title: E3D V6 cooler with BL Touch

description.text:
This is a modification to Tom114's original Prusa inspired cooler and part fan for the E3D V6. It was designed to be a more compact, all in one solution for hotend cooling, part cooling and auto leveling then any available alternative. It adds a mount for the BL Touch from Antclabs, and should be compatible with almost all setups using a direct drive e3d titan extruder, as well as most direct drive and bowden setups that were compatible with tom114's original model. The model uses nut traps for ease of securing the sensor, and should be printed in some form of high-temp material to prevent deformation.

It is important to note that this version is toleranced for the new BL Touch smart version, and may not work with the original classic version. I cannot test it as I do not have a classic on hand. If there is interest I may be able to make a version for the "classic" type sensor, based of reference measurements from Antclabs, leave a comment if you're interested. Good luck on your auto leveling adventures!

Pics should come within the month

Update: ORIGINAL FILE WILL NOT WORK. when tested, the bl touch was to high so the hotend crashed into the build surface in any attempt to level the bed. An updated file has been added which moves the sensor ~3mm lower, which I have found to be an optimal placement in testing the part. It would appear the reference models I used, either the bltouch or v6 ones, were not quite to spec for the physical item. The .step files have not been changed and still reflect the original, incorrect part.

Printer:

Reprap i3-style

No

Supports:

Yes

any works, i use 0.32mm for maximum strength

Infill:

preferably 100 but anything above 20 should work

Notes:

Make sure you print in a plastic that can withstand the temps right next to your hotend
Designed in Fusion 360 with the original fan shroud and grabcad models of the bl touch and V6 as reference.
