description.text:
Hardware for making window security rods out of 3/4" square tube. End caps to "pretty-up" the bar ends, as well as protect the window jamb from sharp edges. Saddles are sized to fit the end caps closely.

Window security rod kits are surprisingly expensive, so this is a solution using cheap, commonly-available 3/4" square stock. PLA does work, but ABS/ASA or nylon are recommended, as window jambs can get very hot in Summer.

title: D300VS Corner Caps (Top and Bottom)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are caps for the corners of a D300VS delta printer. Using these caps allows one to adjust tower position without disassembling the belts or carriers. Parts are sized for commonly-available 5/16" carriage bolts, as the square shoulder of 5/16" carriage bolts is a nice even 12mm (corner-to-corner), which fits the corner section holes perfectly. Shaft of 5/16" bolt is ~8mm, so if you have access to 8mm carriage bolts, they should work as well.

Bottom is for all three corners. Top is for the X and Y towers. Top - Z Tower is designed for the Z tower, where several wires exit the inner slot, and is notched accordingly.

description.text:
Keep that special someone on a leach… or use them as kinky accessories to your outfit.
The 2 parts lock together with M3x30 socket head screws and nut.
Although very durable when printed in PLA, they are breakable in case of emergency. Have fun, but keep is safe!

There are 3 versions:
One version is solid.
Two are designed to hold decorative M4x6 socket screws in a tapped M4 hole. One has printed through holes and one has inside holes. The last one prints nicer since the outside perimeter is printed in one part. The holes have to be drilled afterwards with a 3.2mm drill and tapped M4.

The 2 parts can be printed in one piece without support and seperated after printing. A gentle wiggle and pull on the hinges wil seperate the parts.

title: D300VS Parts Fan Ducts and Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Directed parts fan ducts and mount for the stock Ultibots D300VS Micro Extruder and E3D V6 hotend. Internal geometry of the parts duct contains air guides to spread airflow evenly across the slot. As-tested, produces smooth airflow from just above the tip of the nozzle, down to approximately 2mm below, and converges from 10mm in front and behind the print nozzle, angled inward.

Note: I do not use the thumbknobs on the extruder tensioning bolts, so I do not know if the mount design will cause issues with the stock plastic knobs (I use an allen key chucked into an electric screwdriver, for speed and ease). No bed clearance issues yet detected, but will modify as-necessary to fix bugs.

Bug Fixed: Fan duct relief near the mount needed to be increased - could interface with mount, causing crooked install. This did not happen 100% of the time, so seems to be an as-printed issue. Increased cutout. Also increased fin surface area on first channel in right duct to improve air capture on forward vent - it was a bit weak, and adjusted the mount points to drop the fans 0.5mm lower, to direct less air across the nozzle itself, and improve airflow around the extrusion.

Mount Mk2 uploaded w/updated pic.

FreeCAD exports the left duct with a minor triangle issue, but it does not affect printability or function - as far as I can tell, it has zero effect on anything whatsoever. Since FreeCAD is a bit buggy, I can't find a way to export the left duct file without the reported error (error only reported in KISSlicer - Slic3r-PE doesn't see any problems).

UPDATE: Currently reworking ducts and mount position to improve pressure and angle. This text will change once Mk.3 files are uploaded.

Printer:

Ultibots D300VS

Infill:

20%-30% Recommended

Notes:

Prints well in PLA, PET-G, and ASA. No other materials tested at this time.

This is a little "Jig-clip" piece is designed to go around a 2" ABS pipe and connect to an adjacent pipe with the same "Jig-clip" attached. These clips are designed to connect one to the next and make an array of any size.

Spacing is 100mm between centers.

The result is a bunch of pipes that can stand up on end next to each other. I had a need for this. I have no idea what you might use this for, but you are welcome if it helps somehow.

I hated how my Tronxy X3S functioned. The parts were sub-standard in the kit and nothing fit quite right. After trying multiple different mods to fix the gantry and the x-axis, I began working on my own setup based on multiple different machines I've looked at.

This is a work in progress and more parts will be added as I get this thing worked out.

description.text:
Unbound: Endless War by Anthony Thomas (Cliché Studios – http://www.clichegames.com/)
Unbound:Endless War is a turn based area control strategy game where you place tiles onto the board face down to build the map and leave surprises for your opponent. You control a small fleet of ships and are trying to occupy your opponent's base of operations without letting yours get conquered as well. For example you may surround my base with tiles that are difficult to attack from, or place a hidden explosion hex in the path you think your opponent is going to take to destroy their troops and the nearby hexes.

Info：This is a mini trash can.

Time：About 20 h

Needs

1.A lid is important, it can keep trash hide for users, making the desktop clean and tidy.
2.Easy to open.
3.Allowing users throw trash in different size.
4.Easy to print
5.Save the filament

Solutions

1.A beautiful lid.
2.Use a rotating structure.
3.half open & full open
4.less chamfer
5.Hollow out

description.text:
This was my Christmas vacation project. I wanted to build my own 12v battery box, and the boxes I found didn't have a carry handle. So I used my 3D printer to make one. It is actually several parts that all connect together to make a semi-cool looking system that is easy to get inside when necessary.

The carry handle piece is a remix of: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22819

Parts:

About 1 ft. of 8AWG insulated wire (red and black)
Small Battery Box - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0000B12YQ
40 Amp Breaker - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CSE4E66
12v Voltmeter - https://www.gearbest.com/other-motorcycle-accessories/pp_661629.html
12v DC Socket - https://www.gearbest.com/car-gadgets/pp_120177.html
DC Power Inverter - https://www.amazon.com/Samlex-America-450-Watt-Inverter/dp/B00KXFEVWA

Note: the Samlex 450 inverter sounds a VERY annoying alarm when the input voltage is low. If I had known, I probably would have chosen a quieter inverter.

Good luck if you decide to make this. Happy New Year !

title: VTX Test Rig.  RC Bench Testing

description.text:
Rig for VTX/Camera for Bench tests.

When you want to test an FPV receiver you fire up your race drone, and while you are messing up with your settings, you can forget about time, overheat and burn your VTX on the quad. VTX's are designed to be only powered on the move with lot's of air flowing around otherwise they would come with large heat syncs...

This setup uses 30mm fan that ise blowing on VTX while the power is on so it can stay powered for extended periods of time if needed. The enclosure has exit air vent holes around VTX to prevent it from running hot and overheating.

200mw VTX will suffice for this project, getting 600mw will be overkill and will run too hot.

I used 200mw Aomway VTX
Cheap Eachine CCD camera from banggood
Voltage regulator to step down to 5v for the camera since VTX uses 12v and camera 5v
and 30mm fan. -- This VTX does not provide 5V for the camera.

Printed and assembled, device worked as intend I can leave it powered for long periods of time as long as Lipo battery lasts without any issues.

Printed out of PETG at 260c and 80c bed temp.
When printing with PETG ambient temp is required around 75F - 80F Otherwise your prints will warp. Keep the room warm or build a dollar tree foam board enclosure around your print bed.

PETG in my opinion is better than ABS because it does not release toxic fumes and virtually indestructible. I don't do PLA anymore, it's for kids.

The hinge prints in place as one piece but is held together with detents so in order to use it you need to separate the two parts then put it back in the other way so it sits flush to the OpenBeam. The hinge was initially meant for gluing to a 3mm sheet of Lexan (hence the notch) but you could glue it to just about anything. This part was designed for use with M3 screws. It was printed on a Cell Robox at 20% infill with a nozzle temp of 235C, Bed temp of 115C, an ambient of 60C, and a flow rate of 0.95. Enjoy!

Notes:

Refer to the description for printing information.

title: Tokyo Mauri AA12 Airsoft gun rail

description.text:
This is a modification of the CENA rail posted here

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456475 by malcolmnz

All credit for deisgn goes to the original creator. I modified the bottom rail/tail to make it shorter as my print area was not as tall, also added the sides to "cup" the gun itself as I found it also wobbled a bit when attached.

I also put a bit of a "notch" at the top part where the split is and where it meets the gun, the gun has that pyramid shape that sort of fits into the notch to prevent it from turning on the barrel.

I also found that I ended up using around 30-35mm length M4 socket head screws as anything longer sticks out the other side.

overall size:

Length (front face to longest rail end) 93.25mm
Width rail to rail edge: 68mm
Muzzle hole dia: 23mm
Height top to rail: 70mm

There's an extra part in the STL where I cut the rail, for some reason it showed up when I exported it..prior to printing I just separated the parts and removed that little piece that was left..

remixed_from.author: heartless
remixed_from.title: Folgertech 2020 Prusa i3 X belt tensioner

title: X-axis Tensioner to avoid forces on Z-axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This remix allows you to tension the belt without putting the tension in the belt back through the z-axis linear guides. The tension in the belt becomes a compression force on the x-axis linear guides through the two screws that thread into small nuts pressed into the plate on the end of the axis.

Note: Tensioner.step is the same as Y-Yoke.stl

You will also need:
3mm screws x3
3mm nuts x3
3mm washer x1
3-5mm drill bit (and a tool to run it in)
The bearings, screw, and nut from the original set up on the printer.

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Step 1

Press the 3mm nuts into the hexagonal depressions in the plate

Step 2

Drill two holes in the end of the x-axis in line with the x-axis linear rods. It is helpful to have these slightly oversized.

Step 3

Remove current idler pulley from x-axis on printer, reassemble in yoke.

Step 4

Press a 3mm nut into the slot in the y-yoke.

Step 5

Assemble the plate and the yoke inside the current end of the x-axis.

Step 6

Tighten the outside screws evenly until they press against the ends of the x-axis linear rods. Tighten the middle screw to pull the x-axis belt tight. Tighten all 3 screws as needed.

Remembering the issues I had the first time I tried to get the x-axis belt tight enough, I wanted a way to have a framework that held the x-axis at a constant width no matter how tight I pulled the belt. I started with trying to use some threaded rod, but pretty quickly while looking at other solutions, I noticed that by making the plate in most of the tensioners a little longer, I could turn the linear rods into that framework by drilling a couple holes.

title: Battery Cover Replacement for Little Professor Maths Game

description.text: I have an old Little Professor computer game without a battery cover which means the 9v battery keeps falling out the back. After a few attempts with different designs I settled on this cover which slots in neatly. You can get it out again with a phillips head screwdriver.

Printer:

Cocoon Create 3D Printer Mini (Aldi)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

Infill:

NA

Notes:

I found I needed to use contact adhesive spray with this model to make it stick to the print bed and not curl up around the edges since the model is wide and flat. That adhesive works great to stick strongly and spatulas off fine, however make sure you use a cardboard form to avoid spraying adhesive on the printer moving parts. Note! the adhesive leaves residue behind but I always print with a supporting layer so I don't mind that.
Also, if you print this model, best to flip it upside down so the hooking clip is sticking up, to avoid lots of unnecessary support material.
Clean up using a file to get rid of extra PLA.
Just measured the opening and did a lot of trials.

title: FlashForge Creator Pro Plate Level Block

description.text:
UPDATED FOR BETTER HEIGHT:::

Used to help level bed of creator Pro. Height is 10mm and adjustments should be made after to your filament settings.

This is a work in progress, so report any info that may help with future designing of this.
Idea: To simplify the leveling process for newcomers and experts alike.
Usage: Slips between the platform and bed where the knob springs are. Center platform knob will stop it from going all the way so its easier to take out after adjustment.

NOTE: Will not apply if extruder is not level already. Will void leveling bed. Make sure extruder is level first.

UPDATE: without putting anything on the platform, such as tape etc, I measure a flat 10 mm. So, depending on what you use can affect the height.

author: mojoyup1528

description.text:
Finally it is done, just like the previous mk2's extruder set where I modified them to be compatible with other auto bed leveling probe out there instead of just 8mm size. This one however, also been modified to be interchangeable between the MMU and Direct Drive.

I had to print the parts several times due to the fact that nut's slot sometimes too small for the nuts to go in. The original design was to accommodate square nut, I don't have any square nuts to be used with the parts.

Disclaimer

I hereby do not take credits nor claim the design as my own. This is a modified design of the original prusa i3 mk3 extruder parts to accommodate other probe type than PINDA probe.

I also do not bear any responsibilities for any damage to your printer as this is an upgrade for a seasoned 3d printer owner who knows to change the parts, do firmware tweaking and such. It was your choice as it is your own 3d printer and stuffs too.

Updates

6th March 2018

  • Uploaded the source file "mk3 r1 based.123dx" for you own adjustments
Compatibility

The most essential parts are actually the X-carriage where the width and the gap between both of the x-axis smooth rods are similar across most printers uses smooth rods instead of the aluminum profiles.

The chances are high no matter the brand name is. If it is not compatible but you still want to have it, you might want to transition to a 3d printed x-axis parts.

What To Print?

It is important to print each one of the parts in order to complete the transition from the previous extruder design to the MK3 extruder design

  • x-carriage-back.stl
  • x-carriage.stl
  • extruder-cover.stl
  • nozzle-fan.stl
  • preferred extruder parts
  • 2 x BLTouch spacer.stl (if you're using bltouch)
  • prusa mmu jig at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2583563 (If you're going for MMU)
About the Parts

If you're going to print them, there are 2 types of each hotend which is T1 and T2, both actually are the same except for the overhang parts, Refer to the image to see the differences. I used the T2.

It depends on what probe that you have and what you're going to use. The available options are 8,10,12mm and BLTouch. Choose whichever you want to use.

They are not compatible with the MK2 parts as they have different screw hole positions

Difference between T1 and T2

1/60th Model of Rocket Labs Electron Rocket.
Designed from pictures and wiki for height and diameter.

Electron is a two-stage launch vehicle which uses Rocket Lab's Rutherford liquid engines on both stages. The vehicle is capable of delivering payloads of 150 kg to a 500 km Sun-synchronous orbit.
The Rutherford engine uses pumps that are uniquely powered by battery-powered electric motors rather than a gas generator, expander, or preburner. The engine is also fabricated largely by 3D printing, via electron beam melting

I Designed this to compare the Electron to the Saturn V (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911891) Saturn V in picture is not yet complete missing first stage.

Printed in Black and Grey 0.2mm layer for most. 0.1mm on the little Rutherford's
Need some glue to attach nozzle and tiny tanks on the stage 2 engine. Everything else should press fit.
Some sign writing would finish it of pretty good too.
